newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine stocks close shade higher, seen firm.
newsitem.headline: Argentine stocks close shade higher, seen firm.

text.p: Argentine stocks soaked up early profit-taking and closed firm Friday, cheered by a surge on Wall Street which was not bargained for, dealers said.
"The market followed through on its recent strength thanks to the unexpected turn of events in New York," said Miguel Daneri at Boston Securities.
He predicted stocks would stay firm early next week, weathering bouts of profit-taking due to a steady rise in foreign investment flows into emerging markets.
The blue-chip MerVal index edged up 0.4 percent to 674.93, stretching gains in the week to 3.5 percent.
The MerVal has closed higher in the past five consecutive sessions and stands virtually at a three-year high.

"Argentina's steady economic recovery and expectations surrounding bond placements in the first quarter of the year make it a good choice for emerging market fund managers who are building up new portfolios," said an analyst at a foreign investment bank.

Heavyweight stocks listed abroad as ADRs were the strongest performers in the session, with Telefonica and Telecom jumping 3.1 percent and 2.6 percent respectively. Banco Frances also rose 3.1 percent.
Benchmark stock YPF rose 0.6 percent, taking its week-long bull run to 9.5 percent. Two other blue-chip oil firms, Sol Petroleo and Astra, gained 2.5 percent and 1.0 percent each.

The broad market tacked on 1.0 percent, with winners beating losers 36 to 21 and 19 issues closing flat. Heaviest main-tier losers were pulp maker Celulosa, which tumbled 5.8 percent, and carmaker Ciadea, off 1.1 percent.
Floor volume eased to 25 million pesos from 36.1 million Thursday, while over-the-counter deals picked up to 151.6 million from 124.8 million Thursday.
